element_texts.text:
1840 Memorandum & Diary of J Clyman
Day 1 Light showers of snow a light wind from the NE I am nearly all pealed? with some kind of inflamation so as to scarcely be able to sit up Heard yestarday that the stat bank of Illinois had surrenedered her charter to the Legislature good sleighing = Ross is making a sleigh in yard
Contracted with John Plumb for Building a frame house 42 ft long 14 ft wide with a porch on the S side 14 ft by 10 Plumb to cover and enclose Paid Plumb in advance for the work
John Plumb Dr
? 1 Yoke Steer 65 $45  Bush potatoes $67 50
1 Barrel pork  20$                                       20 $97.50
of all People it seems to me those are the most tiresome who never convers on any subject but their misfortunes
Put on a damp night cap & then relapse
He thought he would have died he was so bad
His Peevish Hearers allmost wish he had

element_texts.text:
2)
1840 Jany 2 Morning overcast with light clouds pleasant winter weather
3d  It snowed moderately nearly all night last night - Fine winter weather Snow 5 or 6 inches deep   Two things Infinite Time and space  Two things more appear to be attached to the above infinity (viz) Matter and number matter appears to prevade the infinity of space and number attempts to define the Quantity of matter as will as to give  bounds to space - which continually Expands before matter and number - and all human speculation is here bounden in matter and number leaving space at least allmost completely untouched.   About the year 650 from the founding of Rome the difficulties commenced Between Marius and Sylla from which I date the commencement of the decline of the Roman commonwealth

element_texts.text:
3)
1840  Jany 4th Fine fair day
Sent to Town for Medicien have been confined to the house for 2 weeks  During the years from 1823 to 1827 I passed my time with furr Traders on & about the Region of the Main Chain of the Rockey Mountains and had frequent opportunities for observation and have frequently thought that the great Quantities of mud Brot down by the Misourie was owing to the whole Region of the main mountain chain hving at some remote period been burned and torn to pieces by internal volcanic eruptions & as in that high and dreary region there is continual and never varying strong west wind blowing the as his mileed? would be continually carried and lodged on the Eastern verge of the mountain owing to its dry Chimical and vitrious Qualities it never yet has been sufficiently saturated to give it solidity but is carried away continually in prdegious large Quantities in the spring season when the snow thaws the water on many large tracts being almost as thick as it can move.

4)
1840 Jany 5 This morning has some appearance for a thaw
Sent some money to town yesterday & got it Exchanged at the Brokers Office paid 15 per cent for Exchang

 Cash ILL Paper 110 $ Dr
 To Exchang By Broker                        16.50

Bot Medicine of ?ovt? Castteman? Unpd
Every Person that has ever passed through the western country must have observed the Quantity of Granite Boulders that lay scattered all over the vast extent of country north west of the Ohio River and which seem to grow larger and more plenty in allmost Regular progression as you traverse the Region northward from the mouth of the Ohio as more of this rock is found in regular strata it has been matter of much speculation to know how they came situate where they are as likewise where they came from and as all Speculation on this head must be mere conjecture my opinion is that remote period the whole of the Missisippi valy was covered with water at which time those

element_texts.text:
5)
1840  Jany 6  Snowed lightly all day yesterday and last night Still Shews like thawing

   Bot of Mr Eggleston 3.600 feet of oak lumber at 5$ per M? ____  18.00

rocks were brought from the base of the Rocky Mountains in the ice and carried southward were let lose? as they progressed by the thaws sunk where they are now found  some have thought that they were seen lying in Regular pairing on the prairey of Illinois But from my own observation I see nothing to confirm that Singular idea
_____________   __________________     _____________________________
In our passage from the headwaters of White River of the Misouri to the Shanon River we passed over a high and most singular Tract of country of about 15 or 20 miles from East to west how far it Extends N. & S I cannot tell it is almost Completely clear of vegetation nothing growing except here and there a stinted prickly pair the soil being of a most loose sterile nature possible and the appearance extremely singular it having been all carried away by the thawing of the snows and showers of rain in to ravines of Extreme depth leaving the plain very uneven

element_texts.text:
6)
1840  Jany 7th Quite moderate
And standing full of rounded conical hillocks of pyramidal form some large at the Base and upwards 100 ft hig and all sizes from that down to ordinary hillocks not more three feet high  From its present Shape I would Judge that at about the depth of 50 feet from below the common surface of the earth the top being carried away to that depth from some cause or other perhaps from a greate accumulation of moisture a slight formation of sand stone accum which shields the tops of all the Larger mounds and from which causes unclear present elevation the earth being of all sho? from Light gray to a dark brown and becomes remarkably easyly? saturated on the surface Mixing in large Quantities of with the water the wather when filled with earth has a sweet taste causing those that are under the necesity useing it to be remarkable castius?

element_texts.text:
1840 January 8 Cloudy and warm for the season
After passing through this last — — you arrive at the foot of the Black Hill a region of hills or rather rounded knobs and valleys but without timber and a great scarcity of water although they are finely covered with nutritious grass and herbs.
The Black Hills are the first or most Eastern range of the Rocky Mountains and are generally well wooded with the various species of pine lumber here we observed a peculiar feature in the substrata not found to my knowledge in any other part of this vast range of mountains the formation of straight rock in a vertical pole with a regular stratification of from 4 to 12 feet high and I observed in some deep ravines from 10 to 18 layers on top of each other in nearly a  perpendicular pile some strata having a small inclination one way and some another with the horizon.
This day the anniversary of Battle of New Orleans appears to be almost forgotten no firing salutes 
The — day no gay parties of pleasure

element_texts.text: 9) 1840 Jany. the 9 Cloudy warm & Thawy =no military parade no rich dinners no splendid feasts of Champagne no high sounding patriotic toasts no gay cotilion parties no Bacanalian revelry- all still and quiet Save only the common affairs of life no Bustle no hurrying to + fro no anxious and inquisitive looks- no "unclear" "save?"not then the sound of the woodmans axe or the lonly teamster calling to his sluggish oxen as he slowly drive along How different to the days I have before seen.  So hath passed a many of the greater days of Festivity now forgotten and given place to others like the returning sound of the ancient forest oak which when first uptorn makes a tremendous crash but as it passes the echo  grows more dull more distant untill it is lost in the surrounding   The whole of this forrest of "petrifactions?" appear to have been deeply embeded in the earth By ancient convulsion of the earth and the continual washing away of earth are now bringing them again to the light of day the stumps stand some nearly perpendicular But mostly in an inclining posture some one way & some anther look at page 11

element_texts.text:
10
1840 Jany 10th  Cloudy thawy misting with Rain
After passing the before mentioned Black Hill Range of of Mountains we came into an uneven vally in which the heads of the Shianne and Powder River rises  the former passing the Black Hills and taking an Eastern direction falls in to the Missouri The taking a Northern Route falls in to the yallow Stone River in this vally and on the high of Land

dividing the two river we found a great Quantity of petrifactions  Mostly of the vegatable Kingdom and on the North side of a ridge we pased all most an entire forrest of petrified Timber apearantly of the pine species the stumps of which was standing thick one of which I rode up to and which required some exertion for me to reach the top sitting on horseback the trunk of which lay  scattered along in large chunks the Branches Broken up  more small these petrefactions are very hard and bring fine form

look at page 9

element_texts.text:
11
1860 January 11th. It rained and snowed all night last night this is Terrible stormy with and snow from the East. I do not recollect that I saw any primitive rock in this place except some granite boulders all the rock that I saw being secondary Lime rock although all the petrifactions and even pebble stone are very hard and flinty and in fact all the rock formation in this region is Transition and secondary except it may be the slate beforementioned. I have thought here it would not be uninteresting to give a description of the Buffaloe with its habits althoug they have been so frequently described by others -  The Buffaloe are of the gregarious Class and the females and all the young under three years old go sometimes in immense herds particularly in the fore part of winter when they collect in the lower valies and most Sheltered parts of of the vast plains they inhabit where they remain all winter if not interrupted.  The female keeping quite fat untill the Spring thaws commence when all at once they become verry poor and lean in the course of a few days

element_texts.text:
12
1840 Jany 12th It froze considerably last night
This is probably owing to the peculiarities of this climate which is remarkably dry through the summer and fall months the vegitation having come to full maturity by the fore part of July. The winter snows having nearly all gone by that time the shower all on a sudden cease to fall and the vegitation immediately dries up the earth becomes dry & parched the vegitable matter remaining dry and unbleached with the next springs thaws the winter commencing without rain the first fall being snow which usually commences about the first of November. By this peculiarity of climate the grasses retain nearly all their substance through the long Rocky Mountain winter But to return again to the Buffalos in spring the thaws having commenced the animals becoming poor rapidly the hunter thin is looking daily for white Liver so called in the hunter phrase this white liver is allways from in female that forward with young which peculiarity is no way accounted for The liver instead of being red and bloody as usual becomes of a pale light ash colour

element_texts.text:
13
1840 January the 13th Cloudy Cold & Freezing 
and so tinder that it hardly holds togeather and is a complete lump of fat/ and is considered the most delicate mess ever found in the animal
In the later part of April and through the month of May the female brings fourth their young which are all of a red colour and verry helpless for a few days frequently if the herd should be interrupted and leave the the immediate place the females leave their young and follow the main herd never returning
Immediately after the grass begins to spring the Buffalo Begin to scatter from the lower plains and ascend the more lofty parts of the mountain region in small heards the males generally solitary and alone find their way into the small mountain glens where they remain feeding on the young and tender vegitation and when satiated continually rubbing off the old winters coat against trees rocks banks or any hard body they

element_texts.text:
14
1840 Jany the 14th Cold and Clear
Come across making a low grunting nois not much unlike the grunt of a hog the males which came through the winter nothing but skin and bone now begin to [?] remarkably fast and in 5 or 6 weeks after the young herbage begins to spring they are fine fat fleshy and a good beef as are the females likewise that do not give suckle and from a weatherbeaten light brown they all now become a fine sleek black about the middle of July they again begin to assemble in large heards their running time having commenced a short time previous
This appears to be the night the time of sleep and rest for the vegitable kingdom leafless and frozen they are now taking their rest and maturing the subsistence they received during the last summer it apiars as if the revolution of the earth around the sun was the day & night for the vegitable as is the earths revolution on its own axes

element_texts.text:
15
1840 Jany 15th Clear and verry cold
the time for activity and rest to animal tribes
Sleep is a curious and singular phenomenon in the more active animal as likened in human species nearly all the animals that prefer night time for collecting their subsistance seem to have the peculiar adaption to the taking of a long and torpid sleep in the winter however many animals that would seek subsistance in day light in their nocturnal wild state are so timerous and fearefull of man that they are compeled to take the night for what they would prefer the day and therefore seem to prefer what is entirely contrary to their natural [inclination?]
The velocity of light seems to be the greatest of all known principals unless electricity should be greater some have thought that electricity is instantaneous throughout all universal space. I can hardly think this to be the fact but if it should

element_texts.text:
16
1840 Jany 16 Clear & still more cold
It puts to rest the difficult question of infinity of space for if any known and palpable principle is instantaneous through eternal space then eternal space may be infinite as to bounds and duration and mater may likewise be infinite as to [quantity] and duration But on the contrary if no known palpable or impalpable principle or matter can be found but what is limited by size or time then infinity means nothing more than such an immense map of space matter or time as becomes immeasureable and incomprehensible to all means of comparison for instance
We may comprehend the globe we inhabit pretty fully and even the sollar system but a million of such systems becomes incomprehensible allthough even a million such systems may fall verry short of the quantity of matter in existance throughout the universal kingdom

1840. Jany 17th verry cold but append to moderat a little
But notwithstanding this immense quantity still Finity becomes a part of infinity and the globes being Finnite or measurable so by comparison of one part or particle of infinite matter occupying a speck of space may we gather some crude idea of infinity itself allthough this Idea may ammount to nothing more than to say all things have thier Bounds and limits Space has its bounds and time has its limmits mater occupies all space and time wears out all things some seem to think that infinity means something that can not Even have a beginning nor an end and that if it were possible to move with the velocity of Light for millions and millions of years and even time without limit that you then have not more than set out But admit all this and say that after you have flown with the velocity of light for as many [?] as there is particle of sand included in the

element_texts.text:
18
1840 Jany 18th Quite moderate
whole Solar System even at that immense time and immense Swiftness if you have advanced a Quarter of an inch comparatively you at once give imaginary Bounds to Space although it may not be posible to measure or comprehend but a verry small Quantity of Space or matter
The Jewish History of the beginning and formation of matter gives deffinite bounds as it ware in respect to time but not so deffinite as respects Quantity.  It says in plain words that the grate universal and eternal esence of matter was six days in making or rather in collecting and arainging three of the great globes of our solar System (viz) The earth the sun and moon   The sun however as the center should come first the earth second and in this we have a Tolerable fair history first chapt of Genesis 1st verse In the begining God created the Heaven and the earth -- 
Now here appears to be three distinct periods

element_texts.text:
19) 
1840 Jany 19th Clear & pleasant
The first as to time which is in the beginning T second as to space The Heaven. the third as to matter the earth. Now as to time allthough these could be no time much criterion to the beginning nor no place anterior to space which I take the word Heaven. Here to mean in fact thier could be no measure for time as we now understand the term, untill some matter was brought into actual motion and the first revolution of the first globe of matter would be the actual beginning of all things but in the second verse we read the spirit of god rested upon the waters = which I take to mean that the water then existed in that part of space now occupied by the Earth

Brot Over
1841

          " Patrick Murry 2 Barrell of pork
          Pay Lynde & Farnem   32.00
            "    West      20.00
                  Cornwell   15.00

Cr By Note to Ballance

element_texts.text:
Sep 29 1852
Work on plank road for Company Ways
Sep 29 Ross & catel $3.00

      30     do             $3.00
            hors teams 2   $2.50
              do     do       $2.50
            to timber for culvert 50 feet 5 cents pur foot $2.50

Oct 1   Ross and catel Monday 8/  3.00

      2   span of horses and wagons  2.50
      3   Ross & teams [?]    $4.50
      4   hors teams 2   $2.50
           catel and plow 2 yoak $1.00
          Ross 1 day   $2.00

Oct 5  Ross 1 Day   $2.00

          2 span horses        $2.50
          oxen 1 yoak   .75
                            _________

October 5 1882     $32.25
O  13   hors in 2 span    1.50
